importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Combs was arrested in September 2024, marking the beginning of the legal proceedings that led to his conviction and subsequent appeal plans.
The date of the news article's publication reflects the current status of the legal case, showing that the appeal process is now active and publicly acknowledged.
The sentencing hearing occurred in September, during which Combs expressed remorse and requested mercy, setting the stage for the appeal decision.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The nearly two-month trial in 2024 drew international media attention and established the factual and legal foundation for the conviction and subsequent appeal.

keyTakeAways: Sean 'Diddy' Combs has been convicted of two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution and sentenced to 50 months in prison, with a $500,000 fine and five years of probation.
Combs was acquitted on charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, indicating a split verdict on the severity of the alleged conduct.
His legal team has formally filed a notice of appeal, signaling intent to challenge both the conviction and the sentence.
Judge Arun Subramanian stated that a substantial sentence was necessary to convey accountability for the abuse of women.
Combs expressed deep remorse during sentencing, acknowledging his actions as 'disgusting, shameful, and sick,' and apologized to two women who testified against him.

The prosecution alleged that Combs used his influence in the music industry to run a sex trafficking operation involving coerced 'freak-offs' with male escorts, particularly involving his relationship with Cassandra Ventura and a woman known as Jane.
The case has attracted international media attention due to its high-profile nature and the serious allegations involving power, abuse, and exploitation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean 'Diddy' Combs, a globally recognized music mogul, has been convicted of two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution and sentenced to 50 months in prison, a $500,000 fine, and five years of probation. While acquitted on more serious charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, the conviction stems from allegations that he used his power in the music industry to coerce women—such as Cassandra Ventura and a woman known as Jane—into participating in 'freak-offs' with male escorts. Combs expressed deep remorse during sentencing, apologizing to the women who testified. His legal team has formally filed a notice of appeal, indicating plans to challenge both the conviction and the sentence. The case has drawn international media attention due to its high-profile nature and the serious allegations of abuse and exploitation.
title: Sean 'Diddy' Combs says he plans to appeal sentence and conviction
